✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really good..
I'd say it's a good prompt. If it's for CoC, I'd remove "Test 3" and "Validator 6" to ease on the overflows, but not a requirement.

hmm tried it in haskell and the solution seems to time out for larger numbers, kinda interesting. Here is the code if you want to play around with it

sieve (p:ps) = p : sieve [x | x <- ps, mod x p /= 0]
main = do
    input_line <- getLine
    let n = read input_line :: Int
    let primes = sieve [2..] -- Infinite list of primes
    let primeString = concatMap show primes -- concatenated primes
    putChar $ primeString!!n -- print the nth character
I think 0 <= n <= 10000 is incorrect maybe you forgot one 0 ^^

Interesting Contribution!
(you should delete the other one, though)
oops it lagged when it was uploading and did it twice for some reason
yes thank you

granted i don't know anything in haskell so that's probably the problem lol
If anyone knows how to optimize the solution, please do tell
What do you mean by overflows?
Sorry, I meant time outs due to large prime calculations, not overflows. My python solution would time out on both of those test cases after hacking at it for ~15 minutes.
whoops, just noticed my reply from yesterday wasn't sent for some reason. But i had said that i lowered the max threshold for those test cases to something a little more reasonable.

s(p:r)|p>999=p:r|1>0=p:s[x|x<-r,rem x p>0]
g x=[(s[2..]>>=show)!!(read x)]
main=interact$g
the solution looks cool but i don't really understand what it's doing

first line is sieve; p<999 needed for speed up

>>= is concatMap
in general it's the same as yours

i lowered the max threshold since people said it was too much, which is kinda true i guess. it should work without the optimization now.
s(p:r)=p:s[x|x<-r,rem x p>0]
g x=[(s[2..]>>=show)!!(read x)]
main=interact$g

I don't mind

... but actually the fact that people are afraid of just small optimization with sqrt(n) just scares me... and actually, you don't even need sqrt because * is like 100x cheaper

def is_prime(x):
  if x&1==0: return False
  i=3
  while i*i<=n:
    if n%i==0: return Faslse
    i+=2
  return True

And it's so fast that you can even do this up to 1M in python under 1 sec, because half numbers are even anyways, and almost all others have divisors between 3 and 17. And python may be slow, but not THAT slow

and there are some variations with (i+2)^2 = i^2 +4*i + 2 and each iteration we just need to add 2 to i and 4i+2 to say i_squared and there are not real multiplications because i*4 is i<<2 (that's why I personally love pure C style)
It's fine, just fix it by deleting one to avoid duplicates :)
